body: Actually there might be a bug with the cell offsets. I'll have a look...

Great! I've already made some progress in fixing it, and implementing a few alternative approaches, I just have to write some proper tests. I'll push it to a separate branch so you can have a look, hopefully in a few hours.

Ok, I think the fix is actually a one-liner: We just need to also strain the offsets.

The reason we switched from the variant with the derivatives w.r.t to Rij to the current approach is that you have to resort to quite messy solutions to properly obtain the stress for the Fourier space of the Ewald sum. With the Strain module, you can still take the derivative w.r.t the strain.
Oh yeah, that's a good point!

issue.title: Fix strain

repository.name: schnetpack
repository.description: SchNetPack - Deep Neural Networks for Atomistic Systems

issue.body:
To supplement the discussion in #401, here's a fixed version. However, this version does not work with batches of size >1, because I couldn't figure out how to do the broadcasting for the strain. (You need to go from `[batch * 3, 3]` to batch-resolved pairs or positions...)

[Here's a gist](https://gist.github.com/sirmarcel/7b7f4ddb617c10db4a26dd7e75f1aea5) that computes the stress for a toy LJ example with (a) the standard way of straining the positions/box/offset, (b) straining the pair vectors, (c) directly from the pair vectors, and compares with the analytical form implemented in `ase`. The output is this:

```
strain
[[[ -2.6312544  -2.9801838  -8.266836 ]
  [ -2.9801505  -5.8807836 -13.080653 ]
  [ -8.266743  -13.080667  -33.894806 ]]]

strain_rij
[[[ -2.6312795  -2.9801457  -8.266726 ]
  [ -2.9801457  -5.8808045 -13.080628 ]
  [ -8.266726  -13.080628  -33.894817 ]]]

rij
[[[ -2.6312802  -2.9801457  -8.266726 ]
  [ -2.9801457  -5.880803  -13.0806265]
  [ -8.266726  -13.0806265 -33.89482  ]]]

ase
[[ -2.63129346  -2.98017313  -8.2668025 ]
 [ -2.98017313  -5.88085113 -13.08076411]
 [ -8.2668025  -13.08076411 -33.89520126]]
```

Clearly, the implementations all work in principle. Strangely, the standard way appears to be slightly non-symmetric. This is probably a numerical issue, but I'm not 100% sure...

body: Alright, the PR with some test fixes is in #402, but this doesn't work across batches. I'm sure you can help me with that, though! :)

Ok, I have a fix in #403 

1. The indexing into strain_i with idx_i missing, which aligns it with atom pairs as required by the offsets.
2. Your cells apparently don't have the right shape. They should be (1, 3, 3) before batching.
Should be fixed. now. Let me know if there are still problems.
Thanks for fixing. After changing the shape of `cell` in my tests, the results look reasonable!

Oh, also, just in case the `cell` ends up getting used anywhere: I'm pretty sure the correct way to apply strain to the `cell` would be:
```
inputs[properties.cell] = inputs[properties.cell] + torch.matmul(
            inputs[properties.cell], strain.transpose(1, 2)
        )
```
This is because the `cell` has the basis vectors along the first dimension.

I've updated the [gist](https://gist.github.com/sirmarcel/7b7f4ddb617c10db4a26dd7e75f1aea5) with an example where I explicitly compute the `offsets` during the forward pass; this produces the following with the current `dev` branch:
```
strain_compute_offsets
[[[  -2.6313148  -91.92748   -387.888    ]
  [  85.96726     -5.8808103 -314.20786  ]
  [ 371.3547     288.0463     -33.894863 ]]]

ase
[[ -2.63129346  -2.98017313  -8.2668025 ]
 [ -2.98017313  -5.88085113 -13.08076411]
 [ -8.2668025  -13.08076411 -33.89520126]]
```

Changing to the form above fixes this.
Yup, this works. It may be slightly more readable to just change the line with the `cell` as above, but both seem to be equivalent and give identical results in my improvised test.
